captions.text:
The US city of Atlanta is situated in the
South-Eastern state of Georgia,
near the Southern end of the Appalachian Mountains.

Atlanta is the center of a sprawling metropolitan
area
of five and a half million people, and growing!
Atlanta's downtown is over there on the horizon,

but the rest of the city is a little harder
to see.
It's under all those trees!

Atlanta is blessed with such a thick, continuous
canopy of greenery,

it's often referred to as, 'the city in a
forest!'

Journey through the city's past at the Atlanta
History Center;

from the city's beginnings as a railway terminal
in 1837,

and through the plantation era to the American
Civil War

when the city was almost completely burnt
to the ground.
The museum holds one of the largest collections
of Civil War memorabilia in the country;
but it's not all flags and cannons,

many exhibits focus on the human cost of this
terrible conflict.
Over time the city rebuilt, and boomed.
First the freeways came,
and then the Civil Rights era

when Atlanta took the front seat in the drive
towards racial equality,

earning it the title, 'the city too busy to
hate'.

In 1996 the city lit up again, this time for
the Centennial Olympic Games.

Atlanta got all gussied-up and was presented
to the world,

and it just gets more graceful with every
passing season.

Atlanta today is a dynamic centre of innovation
and investment.

Two of its leading corporations are also major
tourist attractions.
Go behind the scenes at CNN's global headquarters

by taking a guided tour through the television
network
which pioneered 24 hour news.

Nearby, you can learn some ~ but not all ~ of
the secrets
behind another little home-grown product.
At the World of Coca Cola,

travel along a bottling-line and though the
125 year history

of a company that produces over a billion
gallons of cola every year.

Right next door and containing 10 million
gallons of water,

is the Georgia Aquarium ~ one of the world's
largest!
The aquarium features six exhibits,

from cold-water displays featuring Beluga
Whales

to touch-tanks featuring rays, crabs and star
fish.

But by far the biggest attraction is a massive
saltwater tank,

the Ocean Voyager, where you can actually
swim with Whale Sharks.
Atlanta is a city filled with architecture
synonymous with Southern style and grace,

but for a taste of pure 1920s indulgence,
step into the Fabulous Fox!
Like a vision from Arabian Nights,

the Fox Theater features a ceiling embedded
with more stars
than a moonless night in Georgia.
Atlanta has long been an arts-loving community.

One of the world's greatest stories ~ Gone
With The Wind ~
was written and set here.

Visit the humble apartment where novelist
Margaret Mitchell once lived

and worked before her Pulitzer Prize winning
novel set the world on fire.

While Atlanta's favorite novelist dreamed
of bestsellers,

one Atlanta son dared to voice the shared
dream
of millions of African Americans ~ equality!
The Martin Luther King Junior Historic Site

celebrates the journey of one of history's
most inspiring men.
Visit the civil rights leader's humble birthplace,
the museum dedicated to his achievements,

and the Baptist Church where he once preached,
and now lays at eternal rest.
Step a little further back in time
at the Fernburg Museum of Natural History
and the adjacent Science Center,

which examines history and science from the
Big Bang
to more contemporary times.
If you prefer your animals a little more active,

head over to Zoo Atlanta where a fabulous
collection of Giant Pandas,
Gorillas, Giraffes and Rhinos awaits.
For a different kind of wildlife,

spend an hour or two exploring the vintage
emporiums and bars

in Little Five Points, one of Atlanta's many
diverse neighborhoods.

Atlanta wears its gracious parks like a Southern
Belle's ball-gown.

Cool off in Centennial Olympic Park near the
city's downtown,

or stretch out and rest awhile in midtown's
Piedmont Park.

But for the best views of all, head East to
Stone Mountain Park.
Take the scenic train around the 5-mile circumference
of the world's largest exposed granite monolith.

Then mosey on up to the summit via the hiking
trail
or on the Summit Skyride cable car.
There it is again, Atlanta, Georgia,

sitting pretty under all those trees. Waiting,
to be discovered.

comments.text:
Atlanta is a great city! Midtown and Downtown are safe in present day! 
Don't listen to those that are judging the 1990s ATL... I <3 Atlanta!﻿

comments.text:
How is it to live in Atlanta and the rest of Georgia? I'm applying for a 
scholarship to study in Georgia, don't know where I'd be if I get accepted 
exactly but presumably Atlanta. Are they ultra conservative like some parts 
of the US or more tolerant? I mean CNN is kind of the counter to Fox right, 
does that say anything about what the people are like, along with all this 
about African American rights movements? Is Atlanta gay friendly (I'm not 
some fem queen if that helps)? Is it difficult to get around without owning 
a car? Is there a lot to see and do for someone staying a year? If someone 
could help me out that'd be great.﻿
comments.author: Bannicus

comments.text:

comments.author: Bannicus

comments.text:
+Bannicus There are A LOT of liberals living ITP (inside the perimeter) who 
unfortunately will look down on anybody who doesn't align with their 
politics and worldview, so beware not to become an elitist asshat like 
them. The Anomaly sounds like your typical ITPer. They think the world ends 
at I-285 (Atlanta's perimeter highway) and everybody OTP (outside the 
perimeter) is a hillbilly and a racist, which is of course complete 
nonsense. A true testament to their intolerance and ignorance. You are 
selling yourself short if you think there is nothing outside the perimeter. 
Metro Atlanta is truly an extremely diverse area. You will meet all manner 
of people from every background - some good, some bad, but all interesting. 
Bottomline - make up your own mind based on your own experiences. As for 
MARTA, it unfortunately is a shell of other world-class transit systems. It 
is not very convenient to ride because Atlanta is such a spread out place 
and MARTA generally doesn't go where you need to go. I highly recommend you 
get a car to get around. Its just the way it is in Atlanta.
comments.author: Jack Bauer

comments.text:
+Bannicus Georgia, very racist and backward minded I guess what Anomaly 
says is right about the downtown, but go out and you will regret living in 
the stupid state.
comments.author: Xeon Krze

comments.text:
Pretty liberal in Atlanta until you start getting into the suburbs where 
all the asshole conservatives live. Many conservative live in Buckhead as 
well. Lots of hobos throughout the Metro area. Downtown Atlanta is pretty 
smelly. Midtown Atlanta is the most progressive part of the city, in my 
opinion, and is incredibly gay friendly. MARTA is the easiest way to get 
around the city without owning a car but a bike, along with MARTA, really 
helps. Plenty of raves, lounges, and local events if you search the 
Atlanta, GA location through Facebook.
comments.author: The Anomaly

comments.text:
I love Atlanta but it's true about the horrible transportation situation. 
You have to have a car. No public transportation. And even with a car you 
can expect traffic jams that are nightmares. What a native Georgian like me 
would say is if you are visiting plan where you are going and try to stay 
close to it. Since suburban Atlanta goes like 50 miles in all 
directions...pick one. I recommend North toward Marietta and Kennesaw and 
plan on driving delays. Otherwise, the North side tavern and Blind Willie's 
has the best music in the country. The people are great and the trees are 
beautiful. And you have to eat at the famous Varsity restaurant. Great city 
but it's just hard to get around.﻿
comments.author: Joan Rescigno

comments.text:
You know...ppl never mention the fact that Miami, DC, and Boston all have 
smaller city inhabitants when compared to their MSA just like Atlanta. Just 
reading up on Atlanta, I understand why so many other cities are mad. Lets 
see, home to the worlds busiest airport. ..thats why Chicago mad!
Displaced NY as the center of black music, black culture, and black 
entertainment. ..thats why NY is mad!
Just passed Miami as the 8th most populace metro and took Maybach Music 
Group. ..that's why MIA is mad!
Took 19% of the motion picture businesses from Cali..that's why 
LA/Hollywood is mad!
Took Prince Tennis Group and Mercedes Benz headquarters from 
Jersey...that's why NJ is mad! 
That's not bad for a little " country" town...There's more. ..1 of only 3 
American cities to host the summer Olympics. ..Will host the 2015 Nobel 
Peace Prize...only southern cities with a heavy rail system. ..will field a 
MLS soccer team in 2017...Home of Coca Cola, Home Depot, Porsche Cars 
America, American Cancer Society, Hooters, Chick-fil-A, Delta Airlines, 
Bounce TV, CNN, The Weather Channel, Turner Classic Movies, Boomerang, 
Cartoon Network, CDC,...damn it man, do you want more?

﻿

comments.text:
+goldensealz55 hey to each his own, but IMO Toronto's infrastructure is far 
superior to Atlanta, not to mention it's the fastest growing city in North 
America at the moment...

I don't know how many cities you've traveled to but Atlanta's public 
transit is a bit of a mess compared to most large metropolises around the 
world. it may not be completely horrible (like in Houston for example) but 
it has a poor reputation for a reason. 

Toronto may not have a public transit system connected to downtown, but it 
is far more dense and walkable and offers real "city life" comparable to 
Chicago or NYC once you get the urban core.

of course if you're happier in Atlanta there's nothing wrong with that, 
everybody has different preferences :) 
But IMO Toronto is far more cosmopolitan and international...

comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 haha wow that post proves you are dumber than I once thought. 
Just know that the only reason Atlanta has the busiest airport in the world 
is due to connecting flights, not final destinations. Toronto has MANY more 
arriving final destination passengers than Atlanta, and still does not have 
light rail connecting the downtown core with the airport... Funny thing is 
I work in public transit so I can easily see all the holes in your 
argument. MARTA exists in downtown Atlanta, bus, rail and streetcar... You 
say it has nothing which is absolutely 100% wrong. Atlanta is much more 
exciting than Toronto, I've lived in both for multiple years... For you to 
say it's boring is flat out ignorant. Keep googling your facts, I work in 
the industry so duh, keep trolling it won't change the truth.
comments.author: goldensealz55

comments.text:
+goldensealz55 That is totally wrong. There is GO bus that directly takes 
you from the Airport to downtown. It comes every 15 mins. What you are 
referring to is Mass Transit system from Toronto to Downtown.  They are 
already making one. Very soon, Toronto will have train from Airport to 
Downtown. It will open during the Pan America games. 


Atlanta, being the hub of some of the biggest Airlines in US has the 
busiest Airports in the World. Airport is a big part of the economy. 
Toronto, although much more multicultural than Atlanta, is not that busy in 
flights. So connecting Airport with the city makes less economic sense. I 
am referring to underground subway system of Toronto. What you got in 
downtown? Nothing. 

Atlanta is really a boring suburban ugly place. 

Toronto has the SECOND BUSIEST MASS TRANSIT SYSTEM  within USA and Canada 
combined right after NEW YORK CITY!! Google it or deal with it. Do not 
bring Airport excuse. GO buses run from the Airport and the Toronto Airport 
is like 1/3 the size of the one in Atlanta. So duh.
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 I've lived in both Toronto and Atlanta. For you to say 
Toronto has great public transit makes you look like an idiot. Toronto does 
not have any public transit connecting the airport to the city. In Atlanta 
you can take the train from the airport to almost any part of the city for 
$2.50. I have lived in both cities and think that Atlanta is far superior 
to Toronto. All of your arguments are completely wrong, go smoke another 
one.
comments.author: goldensealz55

comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+Alexis Alejo sorry but 447,841 people is not a big city, Atlanta's 
metropolitan area however is quite large, but it's completely sprawl with 
hardly any density.

Downtown, Midtown & Buckhead are located too far apart for any authentic 
"big city" living. No where in Metro Atlanta will you find the walk-ability 
of NY, Chicago, San Francisco or even Boston.

Retail in the city is quite mall based (like the rest of suburban America) 
Hence the popularity of places such as Lennox, Phillips Plaza, etc. 

Keep in mind I'm not putting down Atlanta, it's my favorite southern city 
and personally I appreciate that it's not overcrowded with plenty of 
breathing room. IMO Piedmont park is one of the public city parks in North 
America
comments.author: Christopher Wallace

comments.text:
Not all of the south is as bad as people think. Trust me. I've visited some 
southern states. Atlanta isnt that bad of a city. But other cities i 
recommend for you are Raleigh, North Carolina, and Memphis, Tennessee. I 
have visited those cities. They are really cool. If you go to raleigh, try 
out this huge barbecue restaurant called "The Pit". And right across the 
street is a chocolate factory called "Videri". And for memphis, enjoy great 
music and tennessee style food. Even take a boat ride along the river that 
borders tennessee with the state of arkansas.

comments.text:
Atlanta is a very nice city. Even more so,dare I say, than other cities. As 
someone who has lived in the Deep South all his life and travelled in major 
cities throughout the US, I can tell you that Atlanta has southern charm 
with an urban rush. Atlanta has lots of trees(as stated by the video) and 
so has a sort of "wide open" feeling. When in Atlanta I highly recommend 
The Varsity at least once if you like old fashioned fast food and many of 
its shopping centers including the Mall of Georgia.

comments.text:
A city too busy to hate is referring to the haters that hate on 
Atlanta....Atlanta, being so busy that it doesn't care about it's haters. 
Atlanta has always been open to the lgbt community, the mayor there 
recently came out in support of marriage equality. There is one of the 
largest gay populations there as well, along with one of the biggest pride 
parades in the country.
